  • 1.II.19D

    Markov Chains
    Part IB, 2005

    Every night Lancelot and Guinevere sit down with four guests for a meal at a circular dining table. The six diners are equally spaced around the table and just before each meal two individuals are chosen at random and they exchange places from the previous night while the other four diners stay in the same places they occupied at the last meal; the choices on successive nights are made independently. On the first night Lancelot and Guinevere are seated next to each other.

    Find the probability that they are seated diametrically opposite each other on the (n+1)(n+1)(n+1) th night at the round table, n⩾1n \geqslant 1n⩾1.

  • 3.I.9C

    Markov Chains
    Part IB, 2006

    A hungry student always chooses one of three places to get his lunch, basing his choice for one day on his gastronomic experience the day before. He sometimes tries a sandwich from Natasha's Patisserie: with probability 1/21 / 21/2 this is delicious so he returns the next day; if the sandwich is less than delicious, he chooses with equal probability 1/41 / 41/4 either to eat in Hall or to cook for himself. Food in Hall leaves no strong impression, so he chooses the next day each of the options with equal probability 1/31 / 31/3. However, since he is a hopeless cook, he never tries his own cooking two days running, always preferring to buy a sandwich the next day. On the first day of term the student has lunch in Hall. What is the probability that 60 days later he is again having lunch in Hall?

    [ Note 00=10^{0}=100=1.]

    comment

    Markov Chains
    Part IB, 2006

    A game of chance is played as follows. At each turn the player tosses a coin, which lands heads or tails with equal probability 1/21 / 21/2. The outcome determines a score for that turn, which depends also on the cumulative score so far. Write SnS_{n}Sn​ for the cumulative score after nnn turns. In particular S0=0S_{0}=0S0​=0. When SnS_{n}Sn​ is odd, a head scores 1 but a tail scores 0 . When SnS_{n}Sn​ is a multiple of 4 , a head scores 4 and a tail scores 1 . When SnS_{n}Sn​ is even but is not a multiple of 4 , a head scores 2 and a tail scores 1 . By considering a suitable four-state Markov chain, determine the long run proportion of turns for which SnS_{n}Sn​ is a multiple of 4 . State clearly any general theorems to which you appeal.

The village idiot is given a pot of paint and a brush, and started at post 0 with instructions to paint all the posts. He paints post 0 , and then chooses one of the two nearest neighbours, 1 or N−1N-1N−1, with equal probability, moving to the chosen post and painting it. After painting a post, he chooses with equal probability one of the two nearest neighbours, moves there and paints it (regardless of whether it is already painted).     A gerbil is introduced into a maze at the node labelled 0 in the diagram. It roams at random through the maze until it reaches the node labelled 1. At each vertex, it chooses to move to one of the neighbouring nodes with equal probability, independently of all other choices. Find the mean number of moves required for the gerbil to reach node 1 .

  • Paper 3, Section I, E

    Markov Chains
    Part IB, 2010

    An intrepid tourist tries to ascend Springfield's famous infinite staircase on an icy day. When he takes a step with his right foot, he reaches the next stair with probability 1/21 / 21/2, otherwise he falls down and instantly slides back to the bottom with probability 1/21 / 21/2. Similarly, when he steps with his left foot, he reaches the next stair with probability 1/31 / 31/3, or slides to the bottom with probability 2/32 / 32/3. Assume that he always steps first with his right foot when he is at the bottom, and alternates feet as he ascends.
